title: Thursday, 2nd May 2019
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:04am

Morning!

VV75 morning
BE11:04am

Before we get down to the stocks-up stocks-down stuff ......

BE11:04am

... you may remember me mentioning a few weeks back that the FT's moving offices.

AMALtd hello
Soundbuy Morning
OnYourRight Morning all
Mouselet Good morning capitalists
11:04 am
BE11:05am

Forcing us to clear our desks. Which is turning up all sorts of oddities.

Mouselet I hope those of you with councillors to vote for have voted
OnYourRight Does BE comment on FOMC?
VV75 ah another giveaway?
Mouselet On a non-capitalist note, does anyone know how the recent disastrous flooding in Mozambique has interacted with Paul Murphy?
Soundbuy A feel a competition coming on........
Mouselet It _looks_ as if it's not quite in the same place but I am worried
BE11:06am

You may also remember me mentioning a few weeks back that I'd share pictures of these oddities. But I forgot nearly immediately after saying that.

Soundbuy *I
BE11:06am

However! let's address that now.

Tony Scott morning
11:06 am
BE11:06am

BE11:06am

Look! It's a freebie from the 1991 G7.

Mouselet Shiny!
Excel Developer @Mouselet: only 3 names on my ballot, 2 tories and 1 lib dem. I wanted to vote Labour. I get two choices.

It's a clock! And it still works!

11:06 am
BE11:07am

VV75 sweet travel clock
BE11:07am

In original box. Made in China.

Mouselet They made clocks well thirty years ago. I'm quite impressed they made clocks in China well thirty years ago.
BE11:07am

The first person to email me with the subject heading "I want the crap clock" can have it. firstname.lastname@ft,com

11:07 am
undefined
Soundbuy That's your kids sorted for Xmas then........
Manxish Morning everyone

And onto the serious stuff .......

PeterC Good morning, anything on progress at SN. with the newish CEO
Arash Massoudi, FT @BE is that clock the reason ML starts a few min late all these years?

You might remember me mentioning Tate & Lyle yesterday.

11:08 am
Tate & Lyle PLC (TATE:LSE): Last: 775.40, up 2.2 (+0.28%), High: 780.00, Low: 765.60, Volume: 543.09k
cracklenpop Messi, eh?

OnYourRight If it doesn't have a wifi connection my children will just nod and woalk off

BE11:09am

Well, there is.

VV75 can we talk about Metro Bank later? younger than that clock
11:09 am
BE11:10am

But to be clear, it's RAW.

BE11:10am

We've done a bit of backtesting but not enough to leave off a BIG health warning here.

OnYourRight Time for more sugar puns
BornCynic @Mouselet - I asked about PM's place and BE is quiet so I suspect that it is not good news...............
BE11:11am

The idea traders seem to have on Tate is that there's interest from a French privately owned peer named Roquette Frères.

Mouselet BornCynic: thank you for caring; that's sad
BornCynic @Mouselet - you have to hope that the place was insured.......
11:11 am
BE11:12am

The story goes -- WHICH I EMPHASISE IS MARKET GOSSIP -- that there's been formal contact made and Roquette Frères has provisional financing in place.

BE11:13am

And with that rumour now out in the open, I imagine they will have to say something if it's true.

BornCynic And onto shares - the Stagecoach RNS was interesting (if you are interested in pensions).
BE11:13am

And remember, what they say might be a "not currently" style statement having gone pens down. Denials are difficult to anticipate, particularly when one of the companies involved is French.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

It may also, of course, be nonsense. But we try not to bring you nonsense too often.

BE11:14am

Live price up 1.5%. Good luck everyone.

OnYourRight Tate and Sucre?
undefined

PBateman Nation's favourite safety deposit box operator, please

simple simon any grey on the ongoing Provident / Non-Standard Finance saga?

VV75 looking at that chart since monday afternoon, is exactly the kind you usually see after you've read about a takeover

Metro to start.

Tom Dalgleish Hi BE et al.
Lemmy Contact is part of doing business, having the finance lined up makes a difference. Also with M&A, interesting to see G4S price drifting down daily
Maverick Morning all
11:18 am
BE11:18am

(Sorry, getting a few calls ........)

BE11:18am

.... Okay, so Metro is a disaster. Again.

Costs, revenue, deposits all going the wrong way.

11:18 am
TH11:19am

deposit flight on the back of the whole not understanding risk weightings thing

Mouselet And presumably Metro isn't even particularly worth snapping up, lots of expensive rents plus a quantity of loans of unclear badness isn't what makes a tempting M&A target
BE11:19am

Exactly. January warning damaged its reputation apparently.

Mouselet who would have thought that 'cannot manage risks of loans' might be damaging to the reputation of a newly-founded bank of unclear purpose?
BE11:20am

Which had previously been great because of the dog bowls and the poorly calibrated change counting machines, which is what people seem to want from a bank.

MassimoJ Any grey on Micro Focus? Or is recent weakness related to the SUSE payout?
1966AndAllThat If Metro goes bankrupt I wonder what they will find in all those safe deposit boxes
11:20 am
BE11:20am

IFRS16 on all those safety deposit box centres also proving to be a problem.

BE11:20am

So forecasts are getting reset. Again.

Tony Scott Suspect the dilution coming in Q2 will not help
Sails I read that as 'loans of nuclear badness', which I suppose might be the same thing
Tony Scott then again, a friendly retail bank for one of the Big 6 might be an interesting play
BE11:21am

Here's a wall of numbers from Citi.

Excel Developer Metro - Post Brexit acquisition from USA bank?
11:21 am
BE11:21am

Citi's Take — PPB reports a slightly weak 1Q19 trading, driven by adverse sports results and responsible gambling measures. 1Q19 net revenue growth was 17% to £478m (Citi £489m). 1Q19 Online net revenue growth of +4% a disappointment vs. Citi +17%, with online net revenue growth excl. Adjarabet -1% yoy (Citi: +11%). 1Q19 online sports net revenues -6% with sportsbook staking only +5% (Citi +20%) despite a weak win margin (-100bps yoy, Citi -10bps yoy), exchange revenue growth +1% (Citi flat) and gaming revenue growth 31% (Citi: +34%) or 14% excl. Adjarabet (Citi: +13%). Australia net revenues +20% (Citi: 24%) driven by staking growth of +17% (Citi +12%), but limited improvement in the win margin +20bps yoy to 9.2% (Citi +100bps to 10%). Retail net revenue growth of -2% (Citi -3%) was broadly in-line with expectations, with sports net revenues -5% (Citi -7%) on a lower win margin -110bps yoy to 11.4% (Citi -100bps) but sportsbook staking +4% (Citi +1%), and retail gaming +2% (Citi +3%). US proforma net revenue growth was strong at +47%. Growth rates are constant currency.

BE11:21am

Damnit! Wait! That's Paddy Power!

BE11:22am

Metro is NOT a bookmaker! To be clear!

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Bookmakers are much more profitable.

BE11:22am

Here's Citi on METRO.

TH11:22am

freudian slip there Bryce

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Reiterate Sell, TP 660p — MTRO u/lying 1Q19 PBT of £6.9m was -39% qoq and well below expectations. We expect downgrades to consensus. We have a Sell rating on the shares, which trade at 0.65x TBV; in our view the low multiple makes it harder to justify raising capital for growth and we see a risk the growth strategy breaks down entirely. Metro will complete the committed £350m raise in 2Q19; it will be interesting to see what the level of take up vs previous raises. New TP 660p.

BE11:23am

P&L Miss — Due to weak revenues [-2% qoq to £107.5m, -5% vs Citi, on lower NII] and higher costs [+3% qoq, +2% vs Citi]. Deposits fell 4% qoq & FY19 growth of 20% looks highly unlikely. 1Q19 cost-income was 92% [4Q18: 88%] and MTRO expects FY19 CIR at upper end of 85-90% range [consensus 83%; Citi 88%]. Capital [12.1% CET1R] was in-line. Call focus was growth, NIM, and costs. Post 1Q19, we cut 2019-20E EPS by up to 12%, and longer-term EPS by 4-5%.

Blank canvas good morning all
BE11:23am

FY19 Growth less than 20% — Deposits fell 4% qoq, due to reputational issues after Jan 2019 update. Outflows were from corporates and retail partnerships but core retail deposits were stable. Growth was stable in March and positive in April and FY19 deposit growth will be “materially lower” than 20% target. Loan growth was solid, as MTRO completed the pipeline originated in 4Q18. The LDR is now 100% but should trend back to 85-90% medium term target range gradually; MTRO noted recent changes to underwriting and increases to front-book pricing have impacted pipeline.

Shrink Seems somebody took the clock?
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Actually, that's dull. Let me skip to Barclays.

BE11:24am

Post 1Q19, we cut earnings estimates c20-30%, and retain our cautious stancewith estimates substantially below the Street. We continue to see a challenging outlook given margin pressure/high costs, andexpectations of furthercapital injectionsbeyond2019. Despite share price -c55% YTD, Metrois not cheap at

20x BARCe 2021eEPS, or 0.7x TNAV for low single digit RoTE.We prefer Lloyds/RBS;for more please seeUK banks: Mortgage margin squeeze to ease, 5 Apr.

BE11:25am

.What to expect from thenet interest margin given soft Q1?Net interest margin came in lower than we expected, falling 12bp q/qto 1.64% impacted by increased interest expense under IFRS16 and softasset yields (see Figure 1 for more).We expect further sustained margin pressure, driven by rising funding costs–particularly as Metro looks to issue MREL-compliant instruments from 2H19 –which currently looksprohibitively expensive. Key will be how funding spreads react to the £350m capital raise and potentially obtaining a credit rating.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Can Metromeaningfullymoderate growth to consume less capital?Metro indicated it will likely grow deposits below its targeted 20% in 2019, partly driven byQ1 deposit outflows, although expectsa return to targeted growth in 2020. While this will weigh on the revenue outlook, it should help reducecapital consumption alongsidefalling risk-density as Metro targets lower-risk (and lower margin) lending. Nonetheless, given the weakprofit outlook we see a further equity injectionin 2020 as highly likely.

BE11:25am

We cut underlying PBT estimatesby c20-30%: Drivenby lower revenues as we reducenet interest margin/volumeestimates, partly offset by lower cost and impairments.Our new estimates are c40-50% below pre-Q1 Refintiv consensus on lower revenue.

BE11:26am

Just the 50% below consensus, then.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

And KBW.

Roidster hi all...any clues on indivior - reults out at 12
BE11:26am

Metro remains at a crossroad, with management accurately
calling 2019 a transition year for the company. The upcoming capital headwinds are nothing short of severe, with the first step being the completion of a £350mm common equity raise in Q2 that will actually be dilutive to TBV. Once completed, management will move toward raising its £500mm of MREL qualified debt in 2H19, which at least temporarily should remove any capital overhang on the stock. However, until we see a clearer path toward closing the gap between ROE and balance sheet growth rates, capital will likely remain an ongoing overhang, especially with the timing of AIRB relief remaining uncertain. While we acknowledge that the customer / deposit base Metro has built from scratch would certainly seem to be more valuable than current levels in a global bank valuation context, there are seemingly minimal positive catalysts left to help the shares re-rate over the next 12 months, in our view.

Activists such as ValueAct, Trian and Elliott Management, which often mount proxy battles to gain board seats and change strategy at target companies, have a legitimate influence on public companies. But there is a balance between maintaining discipline on the board to make tough decisions and permitting a minority of investors to pursue their individual interests.

So anyway .... bad quarter for PPB. Longer term the arguments re Paddy Power remain the same -- high profile US business, regulatory stuff largely in the rear view mirror, etc -- but there's no certainty that 2019 will hit targets. Here's Davy.

BE11:57am

Davy incoming:

FATDAZ @excel indeed
BE11:57am

As each long-anticipated regulatory change is implemented, the
Paddy Power Betfair (PPB) investment thesis is becoming more
straightforward. The group (and sector) is not out of the woods –
there is still much to contend with and much work to do. Yet, for
the first period in some time, PPB’s performance appears more
balanced between those divisions, reflecting the group’s
underlying growth prospects (in the US and increasingly Australia)
and those still hampered by either external and/or internal
challenges (Online and Retail). Encouragingly, it suggests that the
prospects for the group’s core operations (ex-US) are also
improving. On the basis of our estimated US valuation, the core
group is trading on an attractive c.9% 2020 FCF yield (and c.12x
2020 PE).
